data.wave_or_subset: Wave 4 (Nov 2007–Apr 2008); analysis focuses on hypertensive adults aged 45+; subsamples split by general health status (good vs poor); management analysis restricted to previously diagnosed hypertensives
data.access_details: Publicly available dataset; received IRB approval at RAND and in Indonesia
data.notes: Blood pressure measured three times by trained nurses; first measurement discarded, average of last two used. Hypertension defined per WHO (systolic >140 or diastolic >90). Under-diagnosis defined as hypertensive at survey but not previously diagnosed by a doctor. Time and risk preferences elicited via hypothetical lotteries and grouped into four categories each. Distance to nearest health center used as access proxy. Probit models estimated and marginal effects reported.

method.description: The study uses IFLS wave 4 data to analyze how education and individual time preferences relate to asymptomatic disease detection (hypertension under-diagnosis) and disease management (frequency of blood pressure monitoring). Discrete choice (probit) models are estimated for the probability of being under-diagnosed among hypertensive adults, and for the probability of monitoring blood pressure in the last month among previously diagnosed individuals. Analyses are performed for the aggregate sample and separately for respondents in good versus poor self-reported general health.
steps: Select IFLS wave 4 respondents aged 45+ with valid blood pressure measurements.
Construct hypertension indicator using average of the second and third BP readings (systolic >140 or diastolic >90).
Identify under-diagnosed individuals: hypertensive during IFLS measurement but not previously diagnosed by a doctor.
Create management outcome for previously diagnosed hypertensives: indicator equals 1 if blood pressure was checked at least once in the month prior to interview.
Assemble covariates: years of education, log per capita household expenditures (PCE), time preference group, risk preference group, distance to nearest health center, sex, age, and age squared.
Split the sample by self-reported general health status into good health (very healthy or somewhat healthy) and poor health (unhealthy or somewhat unhealthy).
Estimate probit models for under-diagnosis (hypertensive sample) and report marginal effects for aggregate and by health status subsamples.
Estimate probit models for management (previously diagnosed sample) and report marginal effects for aggregate and by health status subsamples.
Interpret differences in the effects of education and time preferences across general health groups.
method.models: Probit regression (binary outcome) with marginal effects reported
method.outcome_variable: 1) Probability of being under-diagnosed among hypertensive respondents; 2) Probability of engaging in good disease management (checked blood pressure in the last month) among previously diagnosed hypertensives
method.independent_variables: Years of education; time preference parameter; (also analyzed: risk preference, log PCE, distance to health center, sex, age, age squared)
method.control_variables: Log per capita expenditures (income proxy); risk preference; distance to nearest health center; sex; age; age squared

results.summary: Under-diagnosis of hypertension is widespread in the IFLS sample (≈60% overall; higher among men). Education and time preferences are associated with disease detection and management, but effects differ by self-reported general health. For detection: education reduces under-diagnosis overall and significantly so among respondents in poor health; it is not significant among those in good health. Greater impatience (higher time preference) increases under-diagnosis overall and among those in good health, but is not significant among those in poor health. Better economic resources (higher log PCE) reduce under-diagnosis, and greater distance to health centers increases under-diagnosis, especially among healthier individuals. Women are less likely to be under-diagnosed. For management: more education increases the likelihood of recent blood pressure monitoring, with larger effects among those in poor health; impatience reduces monitoring among those in good health and in the aggregate; higher log PCE is positively associated with monitoring in good health. Risk preferences and distance are not significant for management.

numerical_results.outcome_name: Good management rate (recent BP check; previously diagnosed overall)

metadata.original_paper_title: Education, individual time preferences, and asymptomatic disease detection
